features: [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'e', 'str': 'e deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his is part of a broader phenomenon of short vowel loss in Iranian manuscripts, especially in later copies. This syncope is linked to the 'allegro' (fast) recitation style, particularly prevalent among Zoroastrian speakers in Yazd. In such contexts, unstressed short vowels, including e, are prone to elision, especially in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. While specific examples of e deletion are not singled out from the general rule, it falls under the documented tendency for short vowels to disappear."}]

[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'āu', 'str': 'āu deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his phenomenon is part of a broader tendency for the loss of short vowels in Iranian manuscripts, especially noticeable in later copies. It is particularly characteristic of the Yazdi Behdini recitation tradition, which often features an 'allegro' or fast pronunciation. In this context, unstressed vowels, including u, tend to be elided when they occur before nasals, liquids, and semivowels. While not explicitly listed as a standalone feature solely for u, it is encompassed by the general pattern of short vowel syncope."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'ə', 'str': 'ə deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'Vowel syncope: loss of short ə, especially before semivowels.'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ə', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a for ə', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "While ə is described as a 'shading of a' in Indian manuscripts, and Jackson notes a in Behdini can lean towards an 'inverted a' or 'close to e', this is more of a pronunciation tendency or a description of the vowel's quality rather than a common orthographic substitution in the way ə substitutes i or e"}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ə', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a for ə', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "While ə is described as a 'shading of a' in Indian manuscripts, and Jackson notes a in Behdini can lean towards an 'inverted a' or 'close to e', this is more of a pronunciation tendency or a description of the vowel's quality rather than a common orthographic substitution in the way ə substitutes i or e"}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'n', 'to': 'ṇ', 'str': 'ṇ for n', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'aē', 'to': 'ai', 'str': 'ai for aē', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, specifically the liturgical manuscripts of the school of Bharaoch, inverse spellings of 'aē' for 'ai' are 'frequent'. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'au', 'str': 'au deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his phenomenon is part of a broader tendency for the loss of short vowels in Iranian manuscripts, especially noticeable in later copies. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ə', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a for ə', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "While ə is described as a 'shading of a' in Indian manuscripts, and Jackson notes a in Behdini can lean towards an 'inverted a' or 'close to e', this is more of a pronunciation tendency or a description of the vowel's quality rather than a common orthographic substitution in the way ə substitutes i or e"}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This change is likely related to the rounded pronunciation of ā in colloquial Persian'}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'u', 'str': 'u deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his phenomenon is part of a broader tendency for the loss of short vowels in Iranian manuscripts, especially noticeable in later copies. In this context, unstressed vowels, including u, tend to be elided when they occur before nasals, liquids, and semivowels. While not explicitly listed as a standalone feature solely for u, it is encompassed by the general pattern of short vowel syncope."}]

This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'm', 'str': 'm deleted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'e', 'to': 'ē', 'str': 'ē for e', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a common feature of vowel quantity change observed in Indian manuscripts. It particularly affects final ē, which tends to be shortened to e due to recitation habits. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). This is part of the general confusion of short vowels ('i', 'e', 'ə'). While Indian manuscripts show frequent 'i' for 'ə' and 'i' for 'e', a direct 'a' for 'i' is not highlighted as a distinct feature."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ī', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for ī', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian (Behdini) recitation, the sound of i is described as 'emphatic' and likely 'long', differentiating it from e and ə which tend to be short. This phonological characteristic suggests a tendency for i to be realized as ī. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ṣ̌', 'to': 'š', 'str': 'š for ṣ̌', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'e', 'to': 'ē', 'str': 'ē for e', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a common feature of vowel quantity change observed in Indian manuscripts. It particularly affects final ē, which tends to be shortened to e due to recitation habits. This is considered not merely a quantitative alteration, but also a qualitative shift where the original more open ē transitions to a closer e. This pattern of shortening is prevalent across various Indian manuscript lineages'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'aō', 'to': 'au', 'str': 'au for aō', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "the monophthongization of the diphthong aō into a is noted in Indian manuscripts, though to a 'very lesser extent' than its monophthongization to u"}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'u', 'str': 'u deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his phenomenon is part of a broader tendency for the loss of short vowels in Iranian manuscripts, especially noticeable in later copies. While not explicitly listed as a standalone feature solely for u, it is encompassed by the general pattern of short vowel syncope."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). This is part of the general confusion of short vowels ('i', 'e', 'ə'). While Indian manuscripts show frequent 'i' for 'ə' and 'i' for 'e', a direct 'a' for 'i' is not highlighted as a distinct feature."}]

[{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]
